channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Scarred by War, Ukraine’s Children Face Years of Trauma
item.description: For countless Ukrainian children, the war has brought long-term physical and psychological injuries. Those who have suffered serious physical harm or the loss of a parent now face a challenging path forward.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maryna Ponomariova, 6, whose left leg had to be amputated below the knee after a devastating attack on her home in Kherson, is now learning to walk again with the help of Nazar Borozniuk at Ohmadyt Children’s Hospital in Kviv, Ukraine, earlier this month.

item.title: For Rishi Sunak, Family Wealth From Outsourcing Adds to a Secretive Fortune
item.description: Britain’s new prime minister married into an $800 million stake in Infosys, a company that does not fit neatly into his party’s views on immigration.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.media:credit: Mark Cuthbert/UK Press, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mr. Sunak and his wife, Akshata Murty, during a reception to celebrate the British Asian Trust at the British Museum in February.

item.title: Russia Completes Draft for Ukraine War and Plans No More Call-Ups, Kremlin Says
item.description: The government’s decision to end the draft, which had been met with protests, appeared aimed at maintaining support for the war among Russians.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times

item.title: In Brazil’s Elections, Many Bolsonaro Supporters Expect Fraud
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro has attacked Brazil’s electronic voting system. Now, ahead of Sunday’s elections, many of his supporters believe there will be fraud.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Bolsonaro’s supporters focus their attention on a series of anecdotal apparent abnormalities in the voting process and results, as well as many conspiracy theories.

item.title: Italy’s Hard Right Feels Vindicated by Giorgia Meloni’s Ascent
item.description: Long marginalized politically and ostracized socially, the new prime minister’s supporters sense a chance to give a final blow to the stigma and shame of their association with Fascism.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Giorgia Meloni at her final campaign rally in Rome before the election in September.

item.title: Saudis Find Sympathetic U.S. Ears at ‘Davos in the Desert’
item.description: A Saudi decision to support a cut in oil output infuriated Washington. But at an investment conference in Riyadh, there was plenty of praise for the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly and Vivian Nereim
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The conference has become a magnet for business leaders, drawing more than 5,000 attendees this year alone.

item.title: A Godfather of Chinese Nationalism Has Second Thoughts
item.description: Wang Xiaodong, once called the standard-bearer of Chinese nationalism, now fends off criticisms of being too moderate, even a traitor. “They’ve forgotten,” he said, “I created them.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wang Xiaodong in a Beijing bookstore in September.

item.title: Putin Says Russia Is Battling ‘Strange’ Western Elites
item.description: Ahead of U.S. elections, the Russian leader sounded like some right-wing Westerners, saying his fight is not with those in the West who hold “traditional values.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski

item.title: Effort to Set Vote to Form Northern Ireland Government Hits a Snag
item.description: Britain’s Northern Ireland secretary had been expected to announce on Friday that a new election would be held in December. But a British official failed to set a day for the vote.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
item.media:description: A polling station in May in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Sinn Fein’s victory that month was a watershed in the country’s politics.

item.title: Memorials for 2 Young Women Killed in Iran Galvanize Protests
item.description: For a second day in a row, tens of thousands of demonstrators protested across Iran against the country’s authoritarian clerical rule. The government response on Thursday was again deadly.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: A video distributed on social media on Wednesday showing people marching toward the cemetery where Mahsa Amini, who died after being detained by Iran’s morality police, is buried.

item.title: Iraqi Parliament Approves New Government After Yearlong Delay
item.description: The installation of a new prime minister and cabinet ends a long-running political deadlock, but perpetuates a system plagued by corruption and dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: Putin Wants to Divide Ukrainians. Mykolaiv Is a Test Case.
item.description: In a battered city on Ukraine’s southern coast, salt water runs from the taps and electricity is sporadic. Residents curse Russia, but also express frustration with their own leaders.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

item.title: Australians Come Home After Years in ISIS Detention Camp
item.description: Dozens more Australians, many of them children, are still being held in Syria, but there is hope that the government will soon sponsor more releases.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A scene at Al-Hol detention camp in Kurdish-controlled northern Syria in 2019. Around 55,000 people, mostly women and children, live there in difficult conditions.

item.title: Ukraine’s Army Advances Toward Kherson, as Mud Season Arrives
item.description: Fall rains have turned the earth to sludge, slowing advances at least until the winter freeze, in conditions that have hampered military movement for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier passing the window of a school that was used as a base by Russian forces in Velyka Oleksandrivka, in the Kherson region of Ukraine.

item.title: Russia’s Defense Minister Says Draft Is Complete, and No More Are Planned
item.description: Announced by Mr. Putin in September, the draft sent shock waves across Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Kirill Braga/Reuters
item.media:description: Russian reservists training at a shooting range in the Volgograd region, Russia, last week.

item.title: With the close of his Twitter deal, Elon Musk’s geopolitical influence is set to grow.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Adam Satariano and Chang Che
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Starlink system in use in the Kharkiv region of Ukraine. The system, which can beam internet service to conflict zones and geopolitical hot spots, has become an essential tool of the Ukrainian army.

item.title: Here’s how some Western powers reacted to Putin’s speech.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A Beginner’s Guide to the U.S. Midterm Elections
item.description: What’s at stake, and how does it work? Let’s start with the basics.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: State races could have a huge effect on issues like abortion rights and voting.

item.title: Ukraine accuses Russia of violating international law by placing Ukrainian children in Russian families.
item.description: The transfer of Ukrainian children from occupied territories to Russia and their adoption by Russian families is a potential war crime.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Evgeniy Maloletka/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke rising after shelling in March in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Xi Jinping vs. the People
item.description: How Chinese citizens are responding to Xi’s lengthened rule.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Noel Celis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Yu-Gi-Oh! Creator Kazuki Takahashi Died Trying to Save Others
item.description: Kazuki Takahashi, creator of the internationally famous Yu-Gi-Oh! manga, was found dead in July. At the time, officials did not disclose the circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Peter Endig/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Kazuki Takahashi at the Leipzig Book Fair in Leipzig, Germany, in 2005.

item.title: Ksenia Sobchak, a Kremlin Critic, Leaves Russia
item.description: Ksenia Sobchak entered Lithuania this week.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yuri Kadobnov
item.media:description: Ksenia Sobchak with President Vladimir V. Putin at the Kremlin in 2018, a day after he won the presidential election, in which she had also been a candidate.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: With more than 3,000 turbines, the Tehachapi Pass wind farms around Mojave, Calif., are some of the largest wind-energy generators in the state.

item.title: OSCE Election Observers Warn of Republican Election Deniers
item.description: Attempts by candidates to discredit the integrity of the vote have “snowballed enormously” since the 2020 election, the head of the observation mission said.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.media:credit: Jodi Hilton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voting in the Massachusetts primary last month. A report by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe highlighted a number of concerns for the U.S. midterm elections.

item.title: G.O.P. Senator’s Report on Covid Origins Suggests Lab Leak, but Offers Little New Evidence
item.description: The report, signed by Senator Richard Burr, foreshadows a new wave of political wrangling over Covid’s origins if Republicans gain control of the House or Senate.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Carl Zimmer
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: Security personnel outside the Wuhan Institute of Virology during a visit by the W.H.O. to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, in Wuhan, China, in February 2021.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: The U.S. Economy Grew, Slowly
item.description: Plus the war in Ukraine may boost clean energy and investigations into Chinese outposts overseas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: By The New York Times
item.media:description: Note: Quarterly changes in gross domestic product, adjusted for inflation. Source: Bureau of Economic Analysis

item.title: With Economy Reeling From Ukraine War, Egypt Secures $3 Billion I.M.F. Loan
item.description: The local currency had tumbled against the dollar, and food and energy prices soared in the wake of Russia’s February invasion of Ukraine, adding to the struggles of millions of Egyptians.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A bustling street market in the center Cairo on Monday.

item.title: U.S. Program Aims to Keep Sensitive Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: Portable, lethal and high-tech munitions like Stinger and Javelin missiles are a focus of a monitoring program operating from the embassy in Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: An American volunteer teaching Ukrainian soldiers how to use a Javelin at a base outside Zaporizhzhia in South Eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Why Russia Stole Potemkin’s Bones From Ukraine
item.description: The 18th-century military commander and lover of Catherine the Great helped conquer Ukraine and looms large in the version of history the Kremlin uses to justify the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Fine Art Images/Heritage Images, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A portrait of Prince Grigory Aleksandrovich Potemkin.

item.title: UK Tells Schools They Can’t Ban Afro Hairstyles
item.description: School rules about what styles are allowed that mostly affect Black and mixed-race children are likely to be illegal, a government rights commission said.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Equality and Human Rights Commission (Great Britain)

item.title: Somalia Asks U.S. to Step Up Drone Strikes Against Qaeda-Linked Fighters
item.description: A new administration in Somalia has launched an offensive against Al Shabab, which are also facing an uprising from local militias.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Farah Abdi Warsameh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Shabab fighters outside Mogadishu, Somalia, in 2008. The Somali government wants U.S. military operators to be able to attack groups of Shabab militants who might pose a threat to Somali forces.

item.title: Israeli-Lebanese Maritime Deal Marks a Milestone, With Limitations
item.description: The U.S.-brokered deal has stirred fierce debate in Israel between some who view it as an achievement and others as a dangerous capitulation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lebanese patrol boats in the Mediterranean Sea on Thursday.

item.title: Pentagon’s Strategy Says China and Russia Pose Very Different Challenges
item.description: A new document describes the military’s response to a new era in broad terms and guides Pentagon policy and budget decisions, but it lacks details.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. troops in Fort Bragg, N.C., prepared to deploy to Eastern Europe in early February in response to the crisis in Ukraine.

item.title: Foxconn’s Big iPhone Plant Hit by China’s Latest Covid Lockdown
item.description: An outbreak in Zhengzhou has sent an unknown number of workers at the city’s Foxconn plant into quarantine. It’s a bad time of year for output of iPhones to slow down.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers walking out for a lunch break outside the Foxconn plant in Zhengzhou, China, in 2015.

item.title: The Climate’s Improved Future
item.description: The world has made real progress on climate change.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Walker Pickering for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wind turbines in Western, Neb.

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Is Sending Leaders to Africa for Help
item.description: Officials from Algeria to Mozambique say they hope to take advantage of an abrupt change in a long-unequal relationship.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Melissa Eddy and Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Andreas Rinke/Reuters
item.media:description: President Macky Sall of Senegal welcomed the German chancellor, Olaf Scholz, in May.

item.title: Mexico’s Senate Votes to Eliminate Daylight Saving Time
item.description: The measure, if signed by the president, would not affect the northern region of the country along the U.S. border.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin and Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: ALFREDO ESTRELLA/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mexico City (and most of the rest of Mexico) would stop springing forward and falling back under a measure passed Wednesday by the country’s Senate.

item.title: Putin begins a high-profile address amid fears that he is escalating the war.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Maksim Blinov
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia speaking at the Valdai Discussion Club meeting in Sochi, Russia, last October.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Support for Ukraine wavers.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden met with Defense Department leaders on Wednesday as the White House signaled Russia remained committed to its war in Ukraine.

item.title: War in Ukraine Likely to Speed, Not Slow, Shift to Clean Energy, I.E.A. Says
item.description: While some nations are burning more coal this year in response to natural-gas shortages spurred by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, that effect is expected to be short-lived.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Martin Meissner/Associated Press
item.media:description: Sheep grazing in front of a coal-fired power plant and wind turbines near Luetzerath, Germany, in October, 2022.

item.title: Australian Judge Orders New Trial in Rape Case That Shook Capital
item.description: A former parliamentary staffer is accused of raping a colleague in the defense minister’s office. The judge said a juror had brought an article on sexual assault cases into the jury room against her instructions.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via AP
item.media:description: Bruce Lehrmann, 27, is charged with sexually assaulting a fellow parliamentary staffer, Brittany Higgins, in 2019.

item.title: Biden Faces New Challenges With Coalition on Ukraine Support
item.description: The domestic and international consensus has shown signs of fraying as midterm elections loom in the United States and Europeans face the prospect of a cold winter.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Joe Biden met with Defense Department leaders on Wednesday as the White House signaled Russia remained committed to its war in Ukraine.

item.title: Reports of Looting in Kherson as Ukrainians Battle to Retake the City
item.description: As Russia pressures local residents to leave, a hydroelectric dam outside the city may prove to be a major point of contention.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Russian tank on Tuesday in a field in the Kherson region of Ukraine.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Iran’s Protests Intensify
item.description: Plus Myanmar gets closer to Russia and a dire climate report.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Jing-Mei White Terror Memorial Park (New Taipei City, Taiwan, Museum)
item.media:credit: Eurovision Social Network/Via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Iranian mourners walked toward the cemetery where Mahsa Amini is buried.

item.title: U.S. Looks to Re-Evaluate Ties With Saudi Arabia Over Oil Production Cut
item.description: Saudi leaders decided earlier this month to join Russia in leading a cartel of oil producers to announce cutting production by two million barrels a day, which could raise prices and help Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and the U.S. secretary of state, Antony J. Blinken, during a meeting in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, in July.

item.title: WHO Lists Top Fungi Health Threats
item.description: The pathogens cause infections that kill millions of people each year and often go undiagnosed. Even when identified, a growing number of infections is resistant to the current crop of drugs.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Cultured Candida auris, right, and cultured Candida albicans.

item.title: US Sanctions Target Russian Efforts to Manipulate Politics in Moldova
item.description: Moldova, like its neighbor Ukraine, wants closer relations with the West but has long battled Russian political interference and intimidation.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Vladislav Culiomza/Reuters and Dumitru Doru/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Vladimir Plahotniuc, left, and Ilan Shor, right, were both prominent political figures in Moldova until they were implicated in a vast 2014 money laundering scheme that stole $1 billion from Moldovan banks.

item.title: Dutch Are Investigating Reported Illegal Chinese Police Stations
item.description: Reports by news media and a human rights group say Chinese police forces opened two offices in the Netherlands that are used to intimidate Chinese citizens.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Bart Maat/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The China embassy in The Hague. Dutch authorities are investigating reports that other Chinese-run offices are intimidating Chinese nationals.

item.title: Israeli Blockade in West Bank Angers Palestinians
item.description: To fight a growing insurgency, the Israeli Army has closed off several entrances to a major Palestinian city, harming its economy and stirring more protest.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli Army front-end loader blocking a road in the West Bank town of Huwara, near Nablus, as Palestinians watched.

item.title: Russia Intensifies Its Propaganda Campaign Against Ukraine
item.description: A new push by the Kremlin frames the war as a counterterrorism operation and seeks to rally Russians to support the fight, officials and researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest blessed new military enlistees at a recruiting office in Moscow this month. By framing Ukraine as the potential nuclear aggressor, Russia can ratchet up tensions over escalating the war without incurring the wrath of its population or further undermining support for President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Van Gogh and Monet Museum Protests Spark a Debate About Tactics
item.description: The van Gogh and Monet paintings targeted in recent climate protests were unharmed. But a debate about tactics rages.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Letzte Generation, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Climate activists poured mashed potatoes on the protective glass shielding a Monet painting in Potsdam, Germany, on Sunday.

item.title: Tens of Thousands in Iran Mourn Mahsa Amini, Whose Death Set Off Protests
item.description: While the security forces cracked down on demonstrations across the country, state media reported a deadly attack on a mosque in the southern city of Shiraz, adding to the atmosphere of tension.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:credit: Afp Via Getty Images
item.media:description: This image, posted on Twitter, shows an unveiled woman standing on top of a vehicle as thousands make their way toward Aichi Cemetery in Saghez, Mahsa Amini’s hometown.

item.title: Evidence ‘Invalidated’ in Explosive Report on Mexico’s 43 Missing Students
item.description: This summer, the government said it had uncovered what happened during the 2014 mass abduction. Arrest warrants quickly followed. But since then, the criminal case and the new account have unraveled.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Ronen Bergman and Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Escuela Normal Rural Raul Isidro Burgos (Guerrero, Mexico)
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

item.title: UK Leader Rishi Sunak Faces a Bruising Prime Minister’s Questions
item.description: The opposition’s lines of attack, starting with Mr. Sunak’s choice of home secretary and his wife’s wealth, gave a glimpse of where it sees vulnerabilities in the governing Conservatives.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Carlos Jasso/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, leader of Britain’s main opposition party, said Rishi Sunak’s choice of home secretary was a “grubby deal” that showed him to be “weak.”

item.title: A Social Media Status Update
item.description: Top social media apps are struggling after a decade of dominance.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose
item.media:credit: Jenny Kane/Associated Press
item.media:description: Social media companies are having a troubling year.

item.title: A 23-Million-Year-Old Fossil Is Carried Away by Parties Unknown
item.description: The whale fossil, a cherished local attraction, was taken from a riverbank in broad daylight by two men with a rock saw and chisel, residents say.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bryan Le Dantec /Getty Images
item.media:description: The town of Westport, on New Zealand’s remote West Coast, about 60 miles from where the fossil was taken.

item.title: Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and More: Visiting Mexico City’s House Museums
item.description: Curiosity about the daily lives of the famous draws us to the places they lived. In Coyoacán it’s possible to commune with the ghosts of Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Leon Trotsky and more.
item.dc:creator: Francine Prose
item.media:credit: Adrian Wilson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leon Trotsky, in exile from the Soviet Union, lived at this house in Mexico City’s Coyoacán neighborhood. It is now a museum.

item.title: How Elon Musk Became a Geopolitical Chaos Agent
item.description: The world’s richest man has inserted himself in some of the world’s most combustible conflicts.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz, Adam Satariano and Chang Che
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mark Schiefelbein
item.media:description: Elon Musk, center, met the Chinese Premier Li Keqiang in Beijing in 2019. Mr. Musk has been criticized for statements regarding China’s interest in Taiwan.

item.title: Read Your Way Through Istanbul
item.description: Istanbul is unfathomable: old and new, real and surreal, melancholic and absurd. Elif Shafak, one of its foremost novelists, reveals its secrets.
item.dc:creator: Elif Shafak
item.category: Istanbul: A Tale of Three Cities (Book)
